facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 8 of 1957 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPFLLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 8 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment and order dated the 30th August, 1955,

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated 30th August 1955 of Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 8 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated the 30th August, 1955, of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 8 of 1955 arising out of the judgment and order dated the 10th December, 1954,

facts.text: Special Appeal No. 8 of 1955 arose out of judgment dated 10th December 1954 of Single Judge of Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ No. 1245 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated the 10th December, 1954, of the Single Judge of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ No. 1245 of 1954. S. Narula, for the appellant.

facts.text: Certificate granted by Allahabad High Court on February 3, 1956 under Art. 133(1)(c) of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has been preferred to this Court on the strength of a certificate granted by the High Court of Allahabad on February 3, 1956, to the effect that the case is a fit one for appeal to the Supreme Court under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution.

facts.text: General election to Municipal Board of Bareilly in October 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts, which are number number in dispute, are these. There was a general election to the Municipal 54 Board of Bareilly in October, 1953.

facts.text: Appellant Mangoo Singh and respondent No. 3 Imdad Husain were candidates from Ward No. 15.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Mangoo Singh, and respondent No. 3, Imdad Husain, along with sever- al others, were candidates at the said election from Ward No. 15.

facts.text: Date fixed for filing nominations: October 5, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The date fixed for filing numberinations was October 5, 1953, and the date for scrutiny of the numberinations filed was October 7, 1953.

facts.text: Date for scrutiny of nominations: October 7, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: and the date for scrutiny of the numberinations filed was October 7, 1953. The appellant and respondent No. 3 both filed their numberinations on the due date,

facts.text: Appellant and respondent No. 3 filed nominations on due date October 5, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and respondent No. 3 both filed their numberinations on the due date, and at the time of scrutiny lmdad Husain raised an objection to the numberination of the appellant

facts.text: Imdad Husain raised objection to appellant's nomination at scrutiny on ground of disqualification under cl. g of s. 13-D due to arrears in municipal tax exceeding one year's demand.

anchor.surface_text: and at the time of scrutiny lmdad Husain raised an objection to the numberination of the appellant on the ground that the latter was disqualified under cl.  g  of s. 13-D of the Act for being chosen as a member of the said Municipal Board because he was in arrears in the payment of municipal tax in excess of one years demand.

facts.text: Objection dismissed by Assistant Returning Officer, appellant's nomination accepted.

anchor.surface_text: This objection was dismissed, and the numberination of the appellant was accepted by the Assistant Returning Officer.

facts.text: Poll took place on October 26, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The poll took place on October 26, 1953, and the companynting of votes was done on October 29, 1953.

facts.text: Counting of votes on October 29, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: and the companynting of votes was done on October 29, 1953. Four persons were to be elected from the said Ward,

facts.text: Four persons to be elected from Ward No. 15.

anchor.surface_text: Four persons were to be elected from the said Ward, and the appellant was the third in the list by reason of the number of votes which he had obtained.

facts.text: Appellant was third in votes, declared elected; Imdad Husain fifth, top unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: and the appellant was the third in the list by reason of the number of votes which he had obtained. Imdad Husain was fifth in the list. Accordingly, the appellant was declared as one of the returned candidates, and lmdad Husain was at the top of the unsuccessful candidates.

facts.text: Imdad Husain filed election petition to set aside appellant's election on ground of disqualification under cl. g s.13-D.

anchor.surface_text: lmdad Husain then filed an election petition to set aside the election of the present appellant on various grounds. The only ground with which we are number companycerned is the disqualification under cl.  g  of s. 13-D of the Act.

facts.text: Election Tribunal by judgment dated October 20, 1954 held appellant disqualified under cl. g s.13-D due to arrears exceeding one year's demand.

anchor.surface_text: This election petition was heard by the Election Tribunal and by its judgment dated October 20, 1954, the Election Tribunal held that the appellant was in arrears in the payment of municipal tax in excess of one years demand to which s. 166 of the Act applied and, there- fore, came under the disqualification in cl.  g  of s. 13-D of the Act

facts.text: Appellant paid Rs. 115-3-0 on October 10, 1953, but Tribunal held it did not wipe off disqualification.

anchor.surface_text: It further held that the payment of a sum of Rs. 115-3-0 on October 10, 1953, five days after the date fixed for the filing of numberinations, did number wipe off that dis- qualification, and the appellant was number entitled to the benefit of the second proviso to s. 13-D of the Act.

facts.text: Election Tribunal held no bill presented under s.166 and no demand notice under s.168 served on appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It may be here stated that the Election Tribunal also held that numberbill for payment of the tax was presented to the appellant as required by s. 166, number was any demand numberice served on him as required by s. 168 of the Act.

facts.text: Election Tribunal allowed petition, set aside appellant's election, declared casual vacancy under cl. a sub-s.2 s.25.

anchor.surface_text: On the above find- ings, the Tribunal allowed the election petition, set aside the election of the appellant and declared a casual vacancy under cl.  a  of sub-s.  2  of s. 25 of the Act,

facts.text: Casual vacancy filled by election of third respondent on April 5, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: which vacancy was subsequently filled up by the election of the third respondent on April 5, 1955. The next general elec- tion in the Municipality is due in October, 1957.

facts.text: Next general election due in October 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The next general elec- tion in the Municipality is due in October, 1957. Against the decision of the Election Tribunal,

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition under Art. 226 in Allahabad High Court against Tribunal decision.

anchor.surface_text: Against the decision of the Election Tribunal, the appellant moved the High Court of Allahabad for the issue of a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Chaturvedi J. dismissed the writ application agreeing with Tribunal's view.

anchor.surface_text: The main point urged by the appellant was that the Election Tribunal was in error in its interpretation of cl.  g  of s. 13-D of the Act. Cha- turvedi J. who dealt with the application of the appellant, agreed with the view of the law as expressed by the Election Tribunal and dismissed the application.

facts.text: Division Bench Agarwala and Sahai JJ. dismissed appeal by judgment dated August 30, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then preferred an appeal to a Division Bench of the said High Court. This appeal was also dismissed by Agarwala and Sahai JJ. by their judgment dated August 30, 1955.

facts.text: Relevant facts not in dispute.

issues.text: The question that falls for decision is the true scope, meaning and effect of cl. g of s. 13-D of the U. P. Municipalities Act, 1916

anchor.surface_text: The question that falls for decision is the true scope, meaning and effect of cl,  g  of s. 13-D of the U. P. Municipalities Act, 1916  U. P. II of 1916 , hereinafter referred to as the Act.

issues.text: Whether the relevant date for the operation of the disqualification under cl. (g) of s. 13-D is the date of the poll

anchor.surface_text: The first contention of learned counsel for the appellant relates to and arises out of the expression for being chosen as occurring in the section. The argument is this. It is submitted that a person is chosen as a member of a board when the poll takes place and a majority of voters vote for him as their chosen candidate therefore, the relevant date for the operation of the disqualification is the date of the poll,

issues.text: Whether the disqualification under the second proviso to s. 13-D ceases retrospectively upon payment of arrears after nomination but before poll

anchor.surface_text: We now turn to the second proviso to s. 13-D. The submission of learned counsel for the appellant is that, as stated in the proviso, the disqualification is transient and ceases to operate as soon as the arrears are paid On October 10, 1953, the appellant was no longer disqualified and, therefore, he could be chosen on the date of the poll, that is, on October 26, 1953.

issues.text: Whether the expression 'to which section 166 applies' and 'demand' in cl. (g) of s. 13-D requires presentation of bill under s. 166 and demand notice under s. 168

anchor.surface_text: the expression to which s. 166 applies in cl. g of s. 13-D means that a bill of the sum due must be presented to the person liable for it, as required by that section, before he can come within the mischief of the clause furthermore, the use of the expression demand makes it essential that a demand notice must also be served as required by s. 168 of the Act.

arguments.claim: Relevant date for operation of disqualification 'for being chosen as' under cl. g s.13-D is date of poll, not nomination

anchor.surface_text: The first contention of learned counsel for the appellant relates to and arises out of the expression for being chosen as occurring in the section. The argument is this. It is submitted that a person is chosen as a member of a board when the poll takes place and a majority of voters vote for him as their chosen candidate therefore, the relevant date for the operation of the disqualification is the date of the poll,

arguments.court_reasoning: Election is continuous process; disqualification attaches at nomination; supported by precedents (Jasani, Ponnuswami) and election rules para 22(2)

arguments.claim: Disqualification under second proviso to s.13-D is transient and ceases retrospectively upon payment of arrears before poll, wiping off nomination-stage disqualification

anchor.surface_text: We now turn to the second proviso to s. 13-D. The submission of learned counsel for the appellant is that, as stated in the proviso, the disqualification is transient and ceases to operate as soon as the arrears are paid On October 10, 1953, the appellant was no longer disqualified and, therefore, he could be chosen on the date of the poll, that is, on October 26, 1953.

arguments.court_reasoning: Proviso has no retrospective effect; disqualification at nomination persists; supported by precedents (Ahmed Hossain, Harford v Linskey) and policy against uncertainty

arguments.claim: Appellant was disqualified under cl. g s.13-D on date of filing nomination due to arrears exceeding one year's demand

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we hold that none of the contentions urged on behalf of the appellant is worthy of acceptance. The election petition was rightly decided, as the appellant was disqualified for being chosen as a member of the Municipal Board in question on the day he filed his nomination, under cl.  g  of s. 13-D of the Act.

holdings.text: If a person is disqualified on the date of nomination, he cannot be chosen as a candidate because the disqualification mentioned in s. 13-D attaches to him on that date.

anchor.surface_text: If a person is disqualified on the date of numberina- tion, he cannot be chosen as a candidate because the dis- qualification mentioned in s. 13-D attaches to him on that date. This is also clear from para. 22 2 of the U. P. Municipali-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Election process is continuous starting from nomination; disqualification attaches at nomination stage as per precedents (Jasani, Ponnuswami) and para 22(2) of election order requiring scrutiny for such disqualifications.

holdings.text: The wiping off of the disqualification under the second proviso has no retrospective effect, and the disqualification which subsisted on the day of filing nominations did not cease to subsist on that day by reason of a subsequent payment of the arrears of municipal tax.

anchor.surface_text: The wiping off of the disqualification under the second proviso has numberretrospective effect, and the disqual- ification which subsisted on the day of filing numberinations did number cease to subsist on that day by reason of a subse- quent payment of the arrears of municipal tax. On this point

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso provides prospective cessation only; no retrospective validation of nomination; supported by precedents (Ahmed Hossain v. Aswini Kumar, Harford v. Linskey) and policy against uncertainty in election process.

holdings.text: the expression to which s. 166 applies cannot bear the meaning sought to be given to it on behalf of the appellant. That expression merely describes the nature of the demand referred to in cl. g .

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of the view that the expression to which s. 166 applies cannot bear the meaning sought to be given to it on behalf of the appellant. That expression merely describes the nature of the demand referred to in cl. g . Section 166 refers to three types of dues el.  a  of sub -s.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Phrase 'to which s.166 applies' qualifies type/nature of tax/dues subject to bill process, not requiring actual bill presentation for disqualification; 'demand' means amount due, not formal notice under s.168, per contextual and dictionary meanings.

holdings.text: Nor do we think that the word demand attracts the operation of s. 168.

anchor.surface_text: Nor do we think that the word demand attracts the operation of s. 168. It may be readily conceded that the word de- mand ordinarily means something more than what is due it means something which has been demanded, called for or asked for. But the meaning of a word must take colour from the context

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Demand' in context means mere amount of arrears or dues exceeding one year's tax, not requiring service of demand notice under s.168; contextual interpretation over ordinary meaning.

holdings.text: none of the contentions urged on behalf of the appellant is worthy of acceptance. The election petition was rightly decided, as the appellant was disqualified for being chosen as a member of the Municipal Board in question on the day he filed his nomination, under cl. g of s. 13-D of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons given above, we hold that none of the contentions urged on behalf of the appellant is worthy of acceptance. The election petition was rightly decided, as the appellant was disqualified for being chosen as a member of the Municipal Board in question on the day he filed his numberination, under cl. g

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects all interpretations favoring appellant; applies cl. g s.13-D to facts, confirming disqualification on nomination date (f9, f10, f18 accepted), no retrospective cure, no need for bill/notice; lower courts correct.

precedents.citation: Chatturbhuj Vithaldas Jasani v. Moreshwar Parashram and Others 1 1954 S.C.R. 817, 821

anchor.surface_text: Chatturbhuj Vithaldas Jasani v. Moreshwar Parashram and Others 1 . In that case the question was when the disqualification mentioned in cl. d  of s. 7 of the Repre- sentation of the People Act, 1951, arose and it was held that the date for putting in the numberinations was one of the crucial dates. On this point, the following observations made in that case are apposite Now the words of the section are shall be disqualified for being chosen. The choice is made by a series of steps starting with the numberination and ending with the announce- ment of the election. It follows that if a disqualification attaches to a candidate at any one of these stages, he cannot be chosen. 1 1954 S.C.R. 817, 821.

precedents.case_name: Chatturbhuj Vithaldas Jasani v Moreshwar Parashram
precedents.cited_proposition: interpretation of 'shall be disqualified for being chosen'; disqualification at nomination stage prevents being chosen as the choice process starts with nomination
precedents.cited_holding: Now the words of the section are shall be disqualified for being chosen. The choice is made by a series of steps starting with the numberination and ending with the announce- ment of the election. It follows that if a disqualification attaches to a candidate at any one of these stages, he cannot be chosen.

precedents.citation: N. P. Ponnuswami v. The Returning Officer, Namakkal Constituency and Others 1 1952 S.C. R. 218

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out in N. P. Ponnuswami v. The Returning Officer, Namakkal Constituency and Others 1  that elec- tion is a companytinuous process companysisting of several stages and embracing many steps of which numberination is one numberina- tion is the foundation of a candidates a right to go to the polls and must be treated as an integral part of the elec- tion. 1 1952 S.C. R. 218.

precedents.case_name: N P Ponnuswami v Returning Officer Namakkal Constituency
precedents.cited_proposition: election is a continuous process consisting of several stages including nomination, which is integral part
precedents.cited_holding: election is a companytinuous process companysisting of several stages and embracing many steps of which numberination is one numberina- tion is the foundation of a candidates a right to go to the polls and must be treated as an integral part of the elec- tion.

precedents.citation: Ahmed Hossain v. Aswini Kumar 1 A.l.R. 1953 Cal. 542

anchor.surface_text: On this point we accept as companyrect the view expressed in Ahmed Hossain v. Aswini Kumar 1 , where a similar question under the Bengal Municipal Act  Ben. XV of 1932 , fell for company- sideration. The question was if a person disqualified on the date of numberination companyld shake off his pre-existing disqualification by acquiring a new right between the date of numberination and the date of scrutiny. [...] A.l.R. 1953 Cal. 542.

precedents.cited_proposition: a person disqualified on the date of nomination cannot shake off the disqualification by subsequent payment or acquiring new right before poll or scrutiny
precedents.cited_holding: if a person was disqualified on the date of the numberination, he companyld number shake off his preexisting disqualification by acquiring a new right between the date of numberination and the date of scrutiny.

anchor.surface_text: There is also other judicial authority which, supports the same view. In Harford v. Linskey 1 , a similar question arose for deci- sion under the Municipal Corporations Act, 1882, s. 12 whereof enacted that a person shall be disqualified for being elected and for being a companyncillor if and while he is interested in companytracts with the Corporation. The peti- tioner in that case admitted that at the time of his numberina- tion he was interested in companytracts with the Corporation, but companytended that he companyld and would have got rid of his disqualification before the day fixed for the poll, and was therefore number disqualified for numberination. [...] 1 1999 1 Q.B. 852, 858.

precedents.cited_proposition: disqualification at time of nomination disqualifies for nomination itself as part of election process; subsequent removal does not retrospectively cure
precedents.cited_holding: a person, who at the time of numberination is disquali- fied for election in the manner in which this petitioner was disqualified, is disqualified also for numberination. The numberination is for this purpose an essential part of the election

justification_sets.label: Section 13-D clause (g), U.P. Municipalities Act, 1916 support
Section 13-D clause (g), U.P. Municipalities Act, 1916 support
